title: Synthesis of Publicly Available Information on Laurent-Philippe Albou

key_findings_with_sources.finding: Laurent-Philippe Albou is a Research Scientist and AI Architect with a PhD in Computational Biology, as stated on his personal website.

Laurent-Philippe Albou is affiliated with the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, as confirmed by multiple sources including the AD Scientific Index, Google Scholar, and the Berkeleybop.org website.

Laurent-Philippe Albou is associated with the Berkeley Bioinformatics Open-source Project (BBOP) at LBNL and has contributed to multiple projects including Gene Ontology, Monarch Initiative, NCATS Biomedical Data Translator, and OBO Foundry.
Laurent-Philippe Albou is listed as an author on 12 academic papers in Google Scholar, with a total of 10,252 citations, including a publication in *Nucleic Acids Research* on ancestral genomes.

Laurent-Philippe Albou is listed as an inventor in French patent applications related to lighting modules and optical devices for motor vehicles, and holds U.S. patents for methods of characterizing molecules and three-dimensional objects.

Laurent-Philippe Albou has engaged with large language models, having liked models such as gemma-3-27b-it, gemma-3-1b-it, and gemma-3-4b-it on Hugging Face, and posted on LinkedIn discussing the use of ChatGPT in the Reactome curation process.

Laurent-Philippe Albou authored the thesis 'Analyse intÃ©grative des donnÃ©es structurales et reconnaissance de forme : application Ã  la rÃ©gulation de la transcription eucaryote', which focuses on structural bioinformatics, protein-ligand binding, and 3D structural analysis in eukaryotic transcription regulation.

knowledge_gaps_with_sources.gap: No verifiable information found for: influence on education

summary: Laurent-Philippe Albou is a research scientist and AI architect with a PhD in computational biology, affiliated with the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and the University of Southern California. His public record includes academic publications, patents, contributions to open-source bioinformatics projects, and engagement with artificial intelligence in scientific curation. He is associated with research in structural bioinformatics, data integration, and semantic technologies, particularly in the context of biomedical knowledge systems.
